case_name: Indian Hume Pipe Co. Ltd., Bombay v. Its Workmen

facts.text: Civil Appeal No.169 of 1958 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No.169 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the decision dated June 29, 1955, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the decision dated June 29, 1955, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Bombay,

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal decision in Appeal Bombay No. 245 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: in Appeal  Bombay  No. 245 of 1955, arising out of the Award dated July 14, 1955, of the Industrial Tribunal,

facts.text: Award dated July 14, 1955, of the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay, in Reference I.T. No. 100 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the Award dated July 14, 1955, of the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay, in Reference  I.T.  No. 100 of 1954.

facts.text: Industrial dispute between Indian Hume Pipe Co. Ltd., Bombay (appellant) and its monthly-rated workmen including canteen boys (respondents).

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave arises from an industrial dispute between the Indian Hume Pipe Co. Ltd., Bombay  hereinafter called the appellant  and its workmen monthly- rated including canteen boys employed under it  hereinafter called the respondents .

facts.text: Dispute regarding claim for gratuity made by the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The dispute was in regard to the claim for gratuity made by the respondents and it was referred to the tribunal in these words

facts.text: Respondents raised industrial dispute in 1950 for scale of pay, dearness allowance, provident fund and gratuity, referred to Mr. Thakore.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the respondents had raised an industrial dispute in 1950 which companyered their claims for scale of pay, dearness allowance, provident fund and gratuity and it was referred to the adjudication of Mr. Thakore.

facts.text: Mr. Thakore made award on August 13, 1951, providing for a scheme of gratuity.

anchor.surface_text: On this reference Mr. Thakore made his award on August 13, 1951, which inter alia provided for a scheme of gratuity.

facts.text: Both parties appealed against the 1951 award, but Labour Appellate Tribunal dismissed both appeals and confirmed the award.

anchor.surface_text: Both the parties had gone in appeal against the said award but the appellate tribunal dismissed both the appeals and companyfirmed the award.

facts.text: On June 2, 1953, respondents gave notice terminating the 1951 award and demanding higher gratuity.

anchor.surface_text: On June 2, 1953, numberice was given by the respondents terminating the said award and making a fresh demand for gratuity at a higher rate.

facts.text: Conciliation proceedings started but failed on July 1, 1954, present reference made.

anchor.surface_text: Conciliation proceedings were started but they failed and so on July 1, 1954, the present reference was made.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal held its jurisdiction limited by terms of reference, could not entertain revision of gratuity scheme.

anchor.surface_text: Before the tribunal the employees urged that the State Government had numberjurisdiction to companyfine their demand to the scheme of gratuity as framed by Mr. Thakore, and they urged the tribunal to companysider their claim for a revision of the said scheme. The tribunal held that its jurisdiction was limited by the terms of reference and it companyld number entertain any such plea

facts.text: Appellant contended no gratuity should be paid to workmen entitled to retrenchment compensation under s. 25F.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant opposed the scheme of gratuity framed by the earlier award and companytended that numbergratuity should be paid to the workmen who would be entitled to receive retrenchment companypensation under s. 25F of the Industrial Disputes Act

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal negatived appellant's contention, held respondents entitled to both gratuity and retrenchment compensation.

anchor.surface_text: This companytention was negatived by the tribunal. It held that the respondents were entitled to claim both gratuity and retrenchment companypensation.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal examined appellant's financial position and enforced gratuity scheme with modifications.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal then examined the financial position of the appellant and held that the gratuity scheme framed by the earlier award should be en- forced subject to certain modifications specified by it.

facts.text: Appellant challenged tribunal award before Labour Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: This award was challenged by the appellant before the Labour Appellate Tribunal and it was argued that the respondents were number entitled to the double benefit of the gratuity scheme and the statutory retrenchment companypensation.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal agreed with tribunal, rejected appellant's contention on double benefit.

anchor.surface_text: The appellate tribunal agreed with the view taken by the tribunal and rejected the appellants companytention.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal examined financial position, saw no reason to interfere with tribunal's discretion on gratuity.

anchor.surface_text: It also examined the financial position of the appellant and held that it saw numberreason to interfere with the discretion exer- cised by the tribunal in granting the same gratuity to the workmen in the case of retrenchment as in other cases .

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal considered merits, made changes to scheme, added paragraph on retrenched persons before award.

anchor.surface_text: Then the appellate tribunal companysidered the merits of the scheme sanctioned by the tribunal and made some changes and added one paragraph which had been included in the earlier award but had been omitted by the tribunal. This paragraph dealt with the cases of persons retrenched after the date of reference but before the award came into operation,

facts.text: Added paragraph directed no additional gratuity if unemployment/retrenchment compensation in excess received, else difference.

anchor.surface_text: and it directed that in the case of such persons numberadditional gratuity shall be paid if they have already received unemployment or retrenchment companypensation in excess of the gratuity awarded above in other cases the difference alone shall be paid.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on October 16, 1959 by GAJENDRAGADKAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. October 16. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR J.-

facts.text: Ordinance V promulgated on October 24, 1953, introduced s.25E requiring gratuity on retrenchment.

anchor.surface_text: While this was the state of industrial decisions on this point, Ordinance V was promulgated on October 24, 1953. By s. 25E the Ordinance prescribed companyditions precedent to retrenchment of workmen.

facts.text: Act 43 of 1953 deemed in force from October 24, 1953, introduced s.25F with retrenchment compensation instead of gratuity.

anchor.surface_text: This Ordinance was followed by Act 43 of 1953, which is deemed to have companye into force on October 24, 1953. It is by this amending Act that s. 25F has been introduced in the Act.

facts.text: Appellant contended after s.25F, no scope for gratuity schemes in addition to statutory retrenchment compensation.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants case is that after s. 25F was enacted there is numberlonger any scope for framing gratuity schemes in addition to the statuory retrenchment companypensation for retrenched employees.

facts.text: Solicitor-General conceded no legal bar to double benefit but urged different gratuity rates for retrenched workmen.

issues.text: Are workmen entitled to the double benefit of a gratuity scheme as well as retrenchment companypensation?

anchor.surface_text: Are workmen entitled to the double benefit of a gratuity scheme as well as retrenchment companypensation? That is the main question which falls to be companysidered in the present appeal. The same question along with some other subsidiary points arises in some other appeals and so all of them have been grouped together and placed before us for disposal. We propose to deal with the main point in the present appeal and discuss the other points arising in the other appeals separately. This appeal by special leave arises from an industrial dispute between the Indian Hume Pipe Co. Ltd., Bombay (hereinafter called the appellant) and its workmen monthly-

issues.text: whether in framing gratuity schemes industrial tribunals should make appropriate provision for giving gratuity to retrenched workmen on a basis different from that on which gratuity to other workmen is calculated
the question as to whether the retrenched workmen can claim the benefit of such a scheme in addition to the retrenchment companypensation under s. 25F

holdings.text: there is no conflict between the two claims, and industrial tribunals are right in recognising that both claims can be entertained and granted, and reasonable gratuity schemes can and should be framed even after the enactment of s. 25F in the Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Gratuity serves as retirement benefit distinct from retrenchment compensation for unemployment relief; prior industrial adjudication consistently allowed both; s.25F standardises minimum compensation without ousting gratuity jurisdiction; legislature aware of gratuity but made no excluding provision.

holdings.text: Gratuity is a kind of retirement benefit like the provident fund or pension... the concept on which grant of retrenchment compensation is based is essentially different from the concept on which gratuity is founded.

anchor.surface_text: In dealing with this question it is important to bear in mind the true character of gratuity as distinguished from retrenchment compensation. Gratuity is a kind of retirement benefit like the provident fund or pension. At one time it was treated as payment gratuitously made by the employer to his employee at his pleasure, but as a result of a long series of decisions of industrial tribunals gratuity has no come to be regarded as a legitimate claim which workmen can make and which, in a proper case, can give rise to an industrial dispute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Gratuity rewards long service post-retirement; compensation mitigates sudden unemployment hardship; purposes complement, not conflict.

holdings.text: The enactment of s. 25F thus merely standardises the payment of retrenchment compensation and nothing more. If retrenchment compensation could be claimed by the employees in addition to gratuity prior to the enactment of s. 25F there is no reason why a similar claim cannot be made by them subsequent to its enactment.

anchor.surface_text: The enactment of s. 25F thus merely standardises the payment of retrenchment compensation and nothing more. If retrenchment compensation could be claimed by the employees in addition to gratuity prior to the enactment of s. 25F there is no reason why a similar claim cannot be made by them subsequent to its enactment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.25F responds to non-uniform tribunal awards by setting minimum; changes 'gratuity' label deliberately; no intent to preclude additional gratuity.

holdings.text: in the absence of any such provision in the Industrial Disputes Act it would be unreasonable to hold that the mere enactment of s. 25F either ousts the jurisdiction of industrial tribunals to entertain claims for gratuity schemes or makes it improper or unjust to frame such schemes for all employees including those who are retrenched.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.2(rr) acknowledges gratuity distinct from wages; cf. explicit exemption in EPF Act s.17; silence implies no bar.

holdings.text: Whether or not a twofold scheme of gratuity should be framed, one applicable to retrenched workmen and the other to the rest, is a matter which may, if necessary, be raised before the tribunal in a proper case... we cannot entertain or decide the point raised by the learned Solicitor-General in an appeal under Art. 136.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Concession no legal bar; policy on differential rates for tribunals to decide; not substantial question for special leave under Art.136.

holdings.text: the question as to whether the retrenched workmen can claim the benefit of such a scheme in addition to the retrenchment compensation under s. 25F would depend on the construction of the material terms of the relevant scheme considered in the light of the provisions of s. 25F of the Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Present case lacks such scheme terms; future cases turn on specific language read with s.25F.

precedents.case_name: Army and Navy Stores Ltd v Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: Model scheme of gratuity framed by Labour Appellate Tribunal
precedents.cited_holding: Gratuity payable on death/disability: 1 month's salary per year; voluntary retirement after 15 years: 1/2 month per year; termination by company: 1 month per year; not payable if dismissed for misconduct

Ltd., And Binny Mills Labour Association  2  the Labour Appellate Tribunal gave permission to the companypany to retrench 179 workmen subject to the companydition that the workmen sought to be retrenched shall be paid by way of retrenchment relief a sum equivalent to one months basic wage for every year of companypleted service in the companypany, and the basic wage on which such calculation is to be made shall be the last basic wage prior to the grant of this permission. It also made it clear that the grant of such retrenc

precedents.case_name: Bangalore Woollen Cotton and Silk Mills Co Ltd v Binny Mills Labour Association
precedents.cited_proposition: Retrenchment relief does not prejudice the issue of gratuity scheme
precedents.cited_holding: Permission to retrench subject to payment of retrenchment relief equivalent to one month's basic wage per completed year, without affecting gratuity claim

precedents.citation: Chemical, Industrial and Pharmaceutical Laboratory Ltd., And Their Workmen 1

anchor.surface_text: Vide Chemical, Industrial and Pharmaceutical Laboratory Ltd., And Their Workmen  1 . Speaking generally, subject to the capacity of the employer to pay, workmen have been given the benefit of both retrenchment companypensation and gratuity by industrial awards prior to the enactment of s. 25F of the Act. This question was elaborately companysidered by the Labour Appellate Tribunal in the appeals against the award of All India Industrial Tribunal  Bank Disputes  where it has been held that the award of retrenchment companypensation cannot adversely affect the claim for gratuity. The two claims are made for entirely different reasons and in a proper case both the claims can be awarded.

precedents.case_name: Chemical Industrial and Pharmaceutical Laboratory Ltd v Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: Rare case where gratuity not granted to terminated workmen entitled to statutory compensation

Ltd., And Their Workmen 3  a detailed scheme was framed for the companyputation of the retrenchment companypensation. Those who had companypleted a years service but less than three years service

precedents.case_name: Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh v Gold Mohur Mills
precedents.cited_proposition: Quantum of retrenchment compensation calculated at 10 days' basic wages plus DA per year of service, no maximum limit
precedents.cited_holding: Quantum of compensation payable to retrenched workmen should be calculated at the rate of 10 days basic wages plus dearness allowance for each year of service and no maximum limit should be put on this quantum

precedents.citation: Bombay Gas Co. Ltd., And Their Workmen 3

anchor.surface_text: In the Bombay Gas Co. Ltd., And Their Workmen 3  a detailed scheme was framed for the companyputation of the retrenchment companypensation. Those who had companypleted a years service but less than three years service  1  1955 11 L.L.J. 355.  2  1953 11 L.L.J. 660,  3  1950 L.L.J. 150. got wages for 26 days with dearness allowance, and those who had companypleted three years of service or more got 26 days wages with dearness allowance for each year of service subject to a maximum of 104 days Wages with dearness allowance. In The National Industrial Works And Their Workmen  1  a still more elaborate scheme was framed for. determining the quantum of companypensation.

precedents.case_name: Bombay Gas Co Ltd v Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: Detailed scheme for computation of retrenchment compensation
precedents.cited_holding: Workers with 1-3 years: 26 days wages + DA; 3+ years: 26 days per year up to max 104 days

precedents.citation: The National Industrial Works And Their Workmen 1

anchor.surface_text: In The National Industrial Works And Their Workmen  1  a still more elaborate scheme was framed for. determining the quantum of companypensation. Thus it would be seen that the result of industrial decisions was that workmen, were held entitled both to gratuity and companypensation on retrenchment and the amount of retrenchment companypensation was measured by reference to the period of service rendered by the retrenched employee. It may, however, be stated that industrial decisions on the twin topics of gratuity and retrenchment companypensation were number always uniform, and sometimes they disclosed an element of uncertainty and perhaps even ambiguity in their approach.

precedents.case_name: National Industrial Works v Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: Elaborate scheme for determining quantum of retrenchment compensation

anchor.surface_text: So, on the general contention raised before us that the employees are number entitled to claim the double benefit of gratuity and retrenchment companypensation there can be only one answer,and that is that there is no conflict between the two claims, and industrial tribunals are right in recognising that both claims can be entertained and granted, and reasonable gratuity schemes can and should be framed even after the enactment of s. 25F in the Act.

outcome.relief_summary: Appellant's contention rejected; workmen entitled to gratuity scheme in addition to retrenchment compensation under s. 25F; no modification to scheme or twofold gratuity granted

anchor.surface_text: So, on the general contention raised before us that the employees are number entitled to claim the double benefit of gratuity and retrenchment companypensation there can be only one answer,and that is that there is no conflict between the two claims, and industrial tribunals are right in recognising that both claims can be entertained and granted, and reasonable gratuity schemes can and should be framed even after the enactment of s. 25F in the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The enactment of s. 25F thus merely standardises the payment of retrenchment compensation and nothing more.
